lesson_title: The Direct Object Marker: Identifying the Target of Action
lesson_summary: This lesson introduces the particle を (wo), which identifies the direct object of a verb. It completes our basic understanding of how nouns interact with actions in the SOV (Subject-Object-Verb) structure.

grammar_explanation.concept: The particle を (wo) is a 'case marker' that identifies the noun immediately preceding it as the direct object of the verb. In logical terms, if the verb is an operation, を marks the data being operated upon.
variations: In some contexts, を can also mark a space through which movement occurs (e.g., 'walking [through] a gate').
common_confusions: Unlike the particle に (ni), which marks a destination or indirect recipient, を (wo) marks the thing directly affected by the action.

teaching_sequence.content: In previous lessons, we learned how 'no' links nouns and 'ni' establishes location. However, a sentence often describes an action performed on something. In Chinese, we put the object after the verb (SVO). In Classical Japanese, we place the object before the verb and tag it with 'wo' (SOV). Think of 'wo' as a logical pointer that says: 'The noun I am attached to is the target of the upcoming action.'

display.text_with_furigana: <ruby>住<rt>すみ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>江<rt>え</rt></ruby>の<ruby>松<rt>まつ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>秋風<rt>あきかぜ</rt></ruby><ruby>吹<rt>ふ</rt></ruby>くからにこゑうちそふるおきつ<ruby>白浪<rt>しらなみ</rt></ruby>
display.romaji: suminoe no matsu o akikaze fuku kara ni koe uchi so furu okitsu shiranami
display.translation: Because the autumn wind blows through the pines of Suminoe, the offshore white waves add their voices to the sound.

vocabulary.chinese_cognate_note: The character 江 (jiāng) suggests a body of water.

vocabulary.meaning: To add to / To join with

teaching_sequence.content: Look at the phrase <ruby>松<rt>まつ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>吹<rt>ふ</rt></ruby>く. In Chinese, you would say 吹松 (chuī sōng). In Japanese, the order is reversed: 松 (Pine) + を (Object Marker) + 吹く (Blows). The particle を tells us that the wind isn't just blowing *at* the pines, but that the pines are the direct recipient of the blowing action.

display.text_with_furigana: くもまよりほしあひの<ruby>空<rt>そら</rt></ruby>を<ruby>見渡<rt>みわた</rt></ruby>せばしつこころなきあまのかはなみ
display.romaji: kumoma yori hoshi ai no sora o miwatase ba shitsukokoro naki ama no kawa nami
display.translation: When I look out over the sky where the stars meet through the gaps in the clouds, I see the waves of the Milky Way.

vocabulary.chinese_cognate_note: Composed of 雲 (cloud) and 間 (between).

vocabulary.meaning: The meeting of the stars (Tanabata festival)
To look out over / To survey

display.text_with_furigana: おほきみのみことかしこみいそにふりうのはらわたる<ruby>父母<rt>ちちはは</rt></ruby>を<ruby>置<rt>お</rt></ruby>きて
display.romaji: ohokimi no mikoto kashikomi iso ni furi unohara wataru chichihaha wo okite
display.translation: Revering the Emperor's decree, I pass the rocky shores and cross the sea, leaving my father and mother behind.

teaching_sequence.question: In the phrase '父母を置きて' (chichihaha wo okite), which word is the 'Target' and which is the 'Action'?
teaching_sequence.answer: '父母' (father and mother) is the Target, and '置きて' (leaving behind) is the Action. The particle 'を' links them.
teaching_sequence.hint: Look for the word immediately before 'を' to find the target.

reference_card.one_liner: Marks the direct object (the 'what') of a verb in an SOV sentence structure.

forward_references.note: We will learn how this links two full clauses in Unit 02.
The 'te' in 'okite' is a linking particle we will cover in the next unit.
